DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 17, 2025
Kathleen Nikesch
WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES KENTWOOD
1715 SUTHERLAND DR,
KENTWOOD, MI, 49508-3306
Re: License #: CB410201260
Dear Kathleen Nikesch:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 29, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not complete a reevaluation and make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the license as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (a) The date the information was received.
One of three special evaluation reports reviewed did not have the report completed
within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
5/22/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/2/2024
2

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (6) An agency shall do all the following:
• (a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of
the report required by subrule (5) of this
rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
One of three special evaluation reports reviewed did not provide the foster parent
with a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of its completion.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster
child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness
or condition that results in treatment
at a hospital emergency room or
inpatient hospitalization of a foster
child.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have documentation an incident report was completed when a
foster youth obtained treatment at a hospital emergency room.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.
3

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
5/22/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/2/2024

5

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of eight foster care files reviewed had a service plan submitted outside of the
required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/22/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/2/2024
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Ensure physical characteristics is up to date on service plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
6

The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 5/22/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 7/2/2024. The agency was cited for 14 violations, 3 of which were
repeated this year. There was an improvement in individual incidents of non-
compliance within all 3 repeated violations. In 2023, 14 violations were
established, 3 of which were repeated this year. Rule 400.12417 (1) (a-h) is
counted as 1 repeat. All of the repeated violations remain close to the same
number of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Special investigation 2025SIC0000167 was completed on 12/17/2024 and the
CAP was approved on 2/3/2025. The agency was found in non-compliance as an
agency foster care worker did not file a complaint with Centralized Intake after
becoming aware of suspected abuse or neglect. The agency's CAP included
retraining staff and updating internal protocol to include requiring supervisor to
document and note timeliness of receiving complaint email from Centralized
Intake.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency has struggled somewhat with staff turnover which has
impacted overall compliance. As a result of the previous year's CAP the agency
has implemented policy and rule refresher trainings that have been useful. The
chief administrator indicated the agency has revised some processes such as
additional trainings and utilization of extended reach to ensure compliance moving
forward.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were interviewed via telephone. Staff reported feeling supported by
coworkers and supervisors. There were no concerns reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
7

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: The licensed foster home failed to respond to multiple attempts by
Agency Analyst to schedule a home visit.
Resolution: A special evaluation was initiated by the agency on 4/10/2025. Licensed
foster parent was found to be in noncompliance with licensing rules. As a result, a
corrective action plan was required that is currently active. Since completion of the
safety alert the agency conducted a home visit on June 12, 2025. The social work
contact indicates a home assessment was completed and there were no safety
concerns.
Safety Alert #2: Licensed foster home is missing smoke alarm outside of master
bedroom and the rest of the home, outside of youth's bedrooms and the rest of the
home and missing in the basement. In addition, the hot tub does not have a locking
cover or rescue equipment. There is also an unapproved room in the basement that
is being used as a bedroom.
Resolution: Two special evaluations were initiated by the agency. The agency
worked with licensed foster parent to purchase additional smoke alarms and move
existing smoke alarms in order to meet licensing requirements. The agency provided
pictures of installed smoke alarms in appropriate locations as verification. A locking
cover and rescue ring were purchased for the hot tub. The hot tub was emptied until
those items were received and foster parent indicated she had no plans on using it
in the near future. The agency provided a picture of the rescue ring and empty hot
tub. Since completion of the safety alert the agency purchased a hot tub lock and
provided a picture of the locked hot tub as verification. In addition, an addendum
was written, signed and put in her file regarding the hot tub in her home. The agency
addressed the unapproved room in the basement with licensed foster parent.
Screenshot of the social work contact was provided by the agency. All concerns
addressed in two special evaluations that resulted in corrective action plans which
have been completed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
8
